awd_titl_txt: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Course:  Frontiers and Techniques in Plant Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory course on Frontiers and Techniques in Plant Science provides opportunities for a diverse group of early career scientists to learn about the latest developments and methods in plant research. This three-week immersion course provides training in the cutting-edge techniques used in modern research on model and crop plants.  The course has a long tradition of exposing students to new ways of thinking about plant research and to new approaches in plant research.  Students who complete this course will be prepared to join the next generation of innovative scientists in the plant research community. 

Frontiers and Techniques in Plant Science is a well-established course on current research and techniques in plant biology.  This course consists of a rigorous lecture series, hands-on laboratory experiences and informal workshops.  The course provides training in plant genetics and molecular biology, genomics and synthetic techniques, as well as analytical, computational and interdisciplinary approaches to plant research.  The course instructors are chosen based on their expertise and substantial contributions to plant research.  The participants are a diverse group of early career scientists who benefit from the intensive laboratory-based coursework and substantial opportunities for networking with leaders in the field of plant research.  Past participants have reported a high satisfaction with the course, and long-term follow-up studies indicate that the course has a long-lasting impact on the careers and research directions of participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Course on: Frontiers & Techniques in Plant Science

June 30 - July 20, 2023

The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory summer course on Frontiers and Techniques in Plant Science (FTPS) has been continuously taught with funding by the National Science Foundation since its inception 30 years ago. Topics have covered a wide variety of plant systems, reflecting current research priorities in many US and international laboratories and the expansion of genome-enabled plant species and technologies.  The course has allowed students to take advantage of a wealth of technological resources applied to biological processes that are unique to plants.  It is designed to fulfill a continuing demand within the plant science community for training in molecular and genetic approaches.  The course teaches state of the art techniques to scientists already involved in plant research so that they can apply these technologies to their own future research and introduces scientists familiar with microbial, animal or plant systems to cutting-edge research carried out by top plant biologists.

 The 2023 course consisted of a rigorous lecture series, a hands-on laboratory, and informal workshops on a variety of research tools.  Speakers provided both an overview of a broad area of expertise and an in-depth discussion of their work.  These speakers included experts in a variety of plant species, research questions and applications, and brought a range of technical expertise to the course.  The laboratory sessions provided intensive training in modern techniques in plant biology and reinforced the lessons learned in lectures.  The lecture topics ranged from plant anatomy to phylogenetics, aspects of morphogenesis and development, plant-environment interactions, hormone signaling, metabolism, cell wall structure, and plants in the context of bioenergy.  The experimental approaches that corresponded to these topics included microscopy to examine gene expression, transformation techniques, isolation of actively translated transcripts through ribosome purification followed by quantitative PCR, biochemical fractionation of proteins, proteomics, and metabolite profiling.  In recognition of the increasing importance of computational methods in plant biology, modules on phylogenetics, QTL mapping, machine vision, and the use of statistical methods for global analysis of transcript, protein, and metabolite levels were included.

Modified by: David J Stewart
